data.text: Water Bladder on Rear Rack of the Bicycle

I'm curious for those who use a water bladder would the tube be long enough to reach from a rear rack bag? I'm thinking a bladder would be easier for me to drink from while I'm moving on the bike but don't really want somthing sweaty on my back.
Your local hardware store may have food safe tubing in the right diameter that they can cut to length for you. Bear in mind that the lower the bladder, the harder you need to suck.
data.author: Ben Beardmore

data.text: Revelate makes frame bags that have holes you can route a hose through if you‚Äôre open to using a frame bag for it.
data.author: RJ Waken

data.text:
There are fanny pack versions that might work for you? Personally, I am not sure I'd want a lot of tubing going between me and a pannier bag. https://www.osprey.com/us/en/product/seral-7-SERAL7S21.html
Seral 7 Lumbar Pack - Biking Hydration Waistpack - 7L - Osprey Packs Official Site
osprey.com
data.author: Alison Clark

data.text: CrankTank4 holds 4 liters and the tube is long enough to position however you'd like. Ships from Australia. The price in whatever the Aussies use at 120 but it's only $60USD with shipping included so it was a no brainer for me.
data.author: Rob Ray

data.text: how do you fill that if you don't have an outdoor tap or a big sink? Most of the time I have to fill up my bottles in gas station bathrooms and things like that.
data.author: Tristan Natsirt

data.text: I use my water bottle and just keep filling it. I haven't tried to fill it in the sink. I'd imagine you'd get a decent amount in it due to the position of the cap
data.author: Rob Ray

data.text: No. However, for the water to travel up from the rear rack then travel for you to drink, would be a bit much. The water needs gravity to feed properly. IJS.
data.author: Mickey L. Foster

data.text: Depends how long the tube is you purchase
data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text:
I bought a water bladder & pack and extra tubing and a hand pump. It worked great. I put the pack on my bike rack and used Velcro wraps to secure the tube in place along my bike frame. https://mazamadesigns.com/
Mazama Designs Hydration Bladders | Reservoirs
mazamadesigns.com
data.author: Ashlea Appelbaum

data.text: I would consider putting it in a frame bag.
data.author: Wacky Gochoco

data.text: Filling the bladder with ice takes care of the sweaty back. It also acts as a personal cooler. Putting it on the bike takes up a whole lot of space that must be used for other things.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: Easy to extend the tube if you need more length.
data.author: Will Taylor

data.text: And consider a quick disconnect link in the tube so you can easily refill the bladder in place.
data.author: Will Taylor

data.text: How long is your ride ? If it‚Äôs hot fill it with ice top off with water I take an extra water bottle with me but have never used it I use my camelbak always stay hydrated
data.author: Clare Kraklow

data.text: You could just put a bladder in a handlebar bag with the tube flopping up, bend toward the bars when you want a sip.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: Just stop have a drink then keep going
data.author: Pdl Breaking

data.text: If you were touring on a recumbent the bag would hang from the Mesh seat back.
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: SmarTube goes from water bottle to your mouth. I haven't seen any long tubes sold seperately , sorry.
data.author: Adrian Cheung

data.text: I made myself a frame bag to fit a bladder and still have room for other things (tiny frame). I haven‚Äôt used it on a real ride yet but had concerns about the tube getting into the spokes. I think I have a workable fix‚Ä¶ To me, that‚Äôs the concern: where is the tube going when you‚Äôre not using it? My solution will require me to stop to drink, but I almost always stop to get a bottle out when riding a loaded bike. I‚Äôm not racing so why risk it? I usually carry slightly larger bottles when touring and there‚Äôs not a lot of clearance with my tiny frame.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: - would be cool to see it! Pics?

data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: never understood them> when i am thirsty, since i am not in a race, I stop and drink. whats the hurry that u need keep peddling while you drink?
data.author: Richard Reitman

data.text: .. Exactly....
data.author: John Lindsay

data.text: different strokes for different folks. I like seeing how far I can go in a set amount of time. I like the physical challenge of it. Just because it's not what you enjoy, doesn't mean its wrong.
data.author: Zachariah O'Dell

data.text: I never said it was wrong... Horses for courses...
data.author: John Lindsay

data.text: also never said it was wrong, jusy]t not understand< i tour to see things not worry about how far i go daily its not a race for me its the journey NOT the destination
data.author: Richard Reitman

data.text: In SA canoeing we use a medical drip bag with a rubber tube glued on for an extension. These bags are very durable. Just a tip is if you use cooldrink which comes as a liquid sirup to dilute with water, then it tends to have some preservatives in which prevent fungus occurring inside the bag. Powder mix cooldrink tends to not have this, and you will get fungus and need to rinse with jick or cleaner for baby bottles.
data.author: Brian Alexander Langton

data.text: Why bother with the faff? You‚Äôre touring, it‚Äôs not a race, just use bottles. üòÄü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
data.author: Peter Atkin

data.text: You can easily extend the tube
data.author: Robert Brown

data.text: Bladders are good for drinking while on the move. Cycle touring is about enjoying yourself. Stop, rest, enjoy the view and use a bottle. Less cleaning problems, no sweaty back.
data.author: Graham Ogle

data.text: There are bottle holders you can attach to handlebars. That way a bottle with a long straw could be used to sip from on the move. You can hot swap drinks and a lot less of a faff refilling than a bladder.
data.author: Law Cheung

data.text: I found the backpack version keeps the sun from beating down on me which is quite intense here in southern AZ. You need to get one with ribs to allow air flow between the pack and your back.
data.author: Melissa Marie

data.text: When I last rode across the USA I put the camelback on a set of tri bars up front. Worked like a handlebar bag...
data.author: Robert Barton

data.text: Food grade tubing and a fitting that will extend your existing tubing will work. Problem might be gravity. The bladder will be lower than your mouth so...you'll be working harder to get water to travel from your rear rack "uphill" to your mouth.
data.author: Rick Hancock

data.text: It‚Äôs easy to get the long tube. The bigger issue is that the lower the bladder is in relation to your mouth, the harder it is to suck the water out. That‚Äôs just a matter of what you are comfortable with.
data.author: Mike Samsen

data.text: In my cycling experience I love to stop and drink. But I never really cared for speed and distance üôà
data.author: Robert Mac

data.text: Aren't the hoses just jammed on to a coupler? If so, then you could easily remove it & replace with a longer hose. OR similar action to put an extension hose between the original hose & the mouth piece. Home Depot
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: i just use mine in an ordinary backpack. The ice idea is a good one
data.author: Davey Nellist

data.text: Stop, enjoy the view, take a photo, have a drink, a snack, give your butt/legs/mind a rest, don't enslave/tether yourself.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: I have my camelback style on top of my trunk and my tube comes up so I can drink out of it.
data.author: Janice Eddington
